stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the Wild West level (Course 12), focusing on implementing a new collision system, designing a bank employee NPC with Zeina, and solving a level design puzzle for a secret entrance. He also discusses his core game design philosophy of 'placeness' and contrasts it with the original Super Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has completely rewritten the game's collision system from scratch to be more robust and reliable than the original SM64 engine. The new system uses a binary search for the largest viable step combined with a raycast, which is faster and safer, though it is still being debugged.
development_findings.quote: Once my new collision system is done, dude, this game will be so nice collision-wise, I think. Much better than any other Mario 64 thing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally designed a secret entrance puzzle to require deduction rather than accidental discovery. He rejected ideas like a fake cardboard cutout as too obvious, settling on a breakable rock that requires the bomb power-up, forcing players to connect story clues.
development_findings.quote: I want players to be like there's a bank robbery. There is moles going around here. Let's go into the tunnel. I don't want them to be like, oh look this looks fake. Let's punch it.

development_findings.summary: A new feature has been implemented where dialogue boxes automatically resize to perfectly encapsulate the text, which Kaze notes is a quality-of-life improvement for development and potential translations.
Kaze is designing a bank employee Koopa NPC, iterating on its appearance to give it an 'old man' vibe with a beard and glasses to fit the Wild West theme.

The project is currently on Course 12 of a planned 15. Kaze is considering rearranging the course order to improve the game's pacing and the balance between story-focused levels and 'placeness'-focused levels.
The 100-coin stars from the original game have been replaced with collectible Yoshi coins.
The new spin jump animation was directly inspired by Mario's Down-B attack in 'Super Smash Bros. Melee' as a more fitting official reference from the era.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the original Super Mario 64's strength is its movement mechanics, but finds its level design to be 'lame' and lacking in 'placeness'—a quality he defines as a level having a distinct theme and feeling like a real place that exists independently of the player.
context_findings.quote: I don't think Mario 64 is that great either, except for the movement design. Like the level design itself is not great, but the movement is like awesome. So that's the part I want to change.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is self-aware of his unique and sometimes esoteric communication style, describing it as a core part of his creative expression that aims for moments of profound connection with his audience.
context_findings.quote: See, I say a lot of really weird things, and like 9 out of the 10 times, you'll just be looking at them and be like, what the fuck are you even talking about? But then 1 out of 10 times, it just hits you and you're like, yeah, this man is speaking to my soul. That's what I'm going for here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with distractions like the loud house heater, highlighting his desire for a focused, quiet environment to work on the project in his basement.
context_findings.quote: All I want to be is in my basement in silence, making Mario.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he moved to North America from Europe, joking that he did it to 'run away from all the taxes.'
Kaze reflects on past projects, stating that 'Zelda: Missing Link' might be the best hack he's made and that 'SM64 Madness' was created in just two weeks but had a lot of 'soul'.

biobak.summary: Biobak is credited as a graphics artist who is 'making a lot of stuff' for the hack.
Kaze notes that a new dynamic text box feature he implemented will be particularly useful for Biobak should he choose to translate the game.

badub.summary: Badub is mentioned as the composer for the project, responsible for 'making a lot of music'.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the new spin jump animation, which was inspired by Mario's Down-B move in Super Smash Bros. Melee.
She designed and provided the textures for the 'Wanted' posters on the town bulletin board, including a joke poster of Kaze being wanted for 'DMCA violation'.
Zeina contributed assets for the bank employee Koopa NPC, including textures for its eyes and a necktie.
Kaze jokingly dismisses Zeina's criticism of his old project 'SM64 Madness', showcasing their playful personal and professional dynamic.
zeina.quote: If I listened to Zeina more, I would be fucked.

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Collision Engine
key_stories.summary: Frustrated by the inherent flaws of the original SM64 physics, Kaze decided to completely rewrite Mario's collision engine. His new, custom system is more stable and performant, enabling more ambitious level design, though it is still a work-in-progress.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 collision system is notoriously buggy and limiting for custom level design. Kaze's previous attempts to fix it with raycasting introduced new problems.
key_stories.process: Kaze designed and implemented a hybrid collision system. It uses a binary search to find the largest possible safe movement step for Mario, combined with a raycast to accelerate the search and other verifications to ensure stability.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a completely new, faster, and more stable collision system from scratch. While still in a debugging phase (e.g., ceiling bonks are broken), it represents a fundamental technical pillar of the project that allows for more complex and reliable world geometry.
key_stories.key_quote: I had an idea yesterday to just rewrite Mario's collision entirely. What you're seeing right now is the rewritten collision.

key_stories.title: Designing an Intentional Secret
key_stories.summary: To guide players to a secret tunnel, Kaze iterated through several designs for its entrance. He rejected an obvious hole and a fake cutout, settling on a breakable rock that requires a power-up. This design choice forces players to connect story clues to solve the puzzle, rather than finding it by chance.
key_stories.challenge: A secret area in the Wild West level needed an entrance that players would discover by following story clues from a bank robbery, not by stumbling upon it accidentally.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a simple, visible hole but rejected it as poor design. He then brainstormed a Wile E. Coyote-style fake cardboard boulder but concluded it was too obvious and would encourage accidental discovery. After weighing the options, he decided a breakable rock requiring a specific power-up was the best way to ensure player intentionality.
key_stories.outcome: The final design uses a distinctly cracked rock that blocks the tunnel entrance. This requires the player to use the bomb power-up, a deliberate action they are more likely to take after gathering clues from NPCs, thus rewarding investigation.
key_stories.key_quote: I want players to be like there's a bank robbery. There is moles going around here. Let's go into the tunnel. I don't want them to be like, oh look this looks fake. Let's punch it.

open_questions.context: Kaze defined his design philosophy of 'placeness'—making levels feel like real, lived-in worlds—and contrasted it with what he sees as the flaws in the original SM64's level design.
